I draw it like this:
1: Draw a body.
2: Draw legs with feet. (Make sure that the legs are longer than the body.)
3: Draw a head.
4: Draw 2 arms with 3 fingers on them. (Arms must be connected to the head.)
5: Draw a face. (Optional)
6: Draw some hair. This will identify the gender.
7: Done. Make a short comic with it.

The equation on the board at 1:20 is wrong. It suppose to be sum of "n", not " 1/n", because is referring to the Riemann-Zeta function of 1, which result is -1/12. The sum on the board is divergent: Zeta(1)=sum(n=1,inf,-1/n)>inf

Human body ratios roughly follow a 3:2:1 ration where Unit 1 = height of the head. The head is 1 Unit, the torso is 2 Units, and the legs are 3 Units. So your stick figures legs should comprise half the total body length.

As a stick figure/fight animator for years I notice everyone develops a distinct style of stick figure animations over time, mine includes:

- Start with the legs, and working up towards the head.

- Make the legs only slightly larger than the upper body, and the arms reach halfway to the thighs in normal circumstances, but for dynamic fights, the arms and legs might sometimes extend a few pixels, but the viewers won't notice that above around 12 fps.

- Instead of hand-drawing the head all the time, copy/paste the letter O as head for every frame when working digitally.

- Have the arms attatched to the back of the head of the stick figure, from the same spot its neck/back is attatched, this is very important for making him flexable and dynamic in stick fight animations.

- Have the forearms and and lower legs be a bit wider and somewhat resambling a cone-shape to reproduce the effect of having hands and feet.
